chapter.title: Hosts
chapter.para: The hosts collection provides information about the hosts in a Red Hat Enterprise Virtualization environment. An API user accesses this information through the rel="hosts" link obtained from the entry point URI (see ).
The following table shows specific elements contained in a host resource representation.

A link to the sub-collection for host network interfaces.
A link to the sub-collection for host tags.
A link to the sub-collection for host permissions. See
A link to the sub-collection for host statistics.
The IP address or hostname of the host
A reference to the cluster that includes this host
The listen port of the VDSM daemon running on this host
true if the host is the storage pool manager (SPM)
Configuration options for host power management. (see )

true if Transparent Hugepages is enabled
The SCSI initiator for the host
Statistics for the host CPU. Includes sub-elements for the CPU's name, topology cores= and speed
Summary statistics of the virtual machines on the host. Includes sub-elements for numbers of active, migrating and total VMs
The compatibility level of the host (see )
The root password of this host, by convention only included in the client-provided host representation on creation

chapter.para: The status contains one of the following enumerative values: DOWN, ERROR, INITIALIZING, INSTALLING, INSTALL_FAILED, MAINTENANCE, NON_OPERATIONAL, NON_RESPONSIVE, PENDING_APPROVAL, PREPARING_FOR_MAINTENANCE, PROBLEMATIC, REBOOT, UNASSIGNED or UP.

chapter.para: Creation of a new host requires the name, address and root_password elements. See for more information.

example.title: Creating a host
example.screen:
POST /restapi-definition/hosts HTTP/1.1 Accept: application/xml Content-type: application/xml
<host> <name>host2</host> <address>host2.example.com</address> <root_password>p@55w0Rd!</root_password> </host>

chapter.para: New host creation applies only to the addition of Red Hat Enterprise Linux hosts. Red Had Enterprise Virtualization Manager detects hypervisor hosts automatically and requires approval for their use.
The root_password element is only included in the client-provided initial representation and is not exposed in the representations returned from subsequent requests.
The name, name, cluster, power_management, transparent_hugepages and ksm elements are updatable post-creation. See for more information.

example.title: Updating a host
example.screen:
POST /restapi-definition/hosts/2ab5e1da-b726-4274-bbf7-0a42b16a0fc3 HTTP/1.1 Accept: application/xml Content-type: application/xml
<host> <name>host3</host> </host>

section.title: Power Management
section.para: The power_management element provides users with the ability to set a Power Management Configuration, required for host fencing. Certain sub-elements are required when configuring power_management.

row.entry: A list of valid fencing device codes are available in the capabilities collection. See .
Indicates whether power management configuration is enabled or disabled
The host name or IP address of the host
A valid user name for power management
A valid, robust password for power management
Fencing options for the selected type=

section.para: The options element requires a list of option sub-elements. Each option requires a name and type attributes. Certain options are only available for specific fencing types as defined in the capabilities collection (see ).
A new host includes an optional power_management configuration when POSTing to the host resource. The power_management configuration is updatable using a PUT request.

example.title: An XML representation of a host's power management configuration
example.screen: <host id="2ab5e1da-b726-4274-bbf7-0a42b16a0fc3" href="/restapi-definition/hosts/2ab5e1da-b726-4274-bbf7-0a42b16a0fc3"> <name>host1</name> ... <power_management type="ilo"> <enabled>true</enabled> <address>192.168.1.107</address> <username>admin</username> <password>p@55w0Rd!</password> <options> <option name="secure" value="true"/> <option name="port" value="54345"/> <option name="slot" value="3"/> </options> </power_management> ... </host>

section.title: Memory Management
section.para: The API provides two configuration settings for a host's memory management.
Kernel SamePage Merging (KSM) reduces references to memory pages from multiple identical pages to a single page reference. This helps with optimization for memory density. KSM uses the ksm element.

example.title: Setting KSM memory management
example.screen:
PUT /restapi-definition/hosts/2ab5e1da-b726-4274-bbf7-0a42b16a0fc3 HTTP/1.1 Accept: application/xml Content-Type: application/xml
<host id="2ab5e1da-b726-4274-bbf7-0a42b16a0fc3" href="/restapi-definition/hosts/2ab5e1da-b726-4274-bbf7-0a42b16a0fc3"> <name>host1</name> <status>UP</status> ... <ksm>true</ksm> </host>

section.para: Transparent Hugepage support expands the size of memory pages beyond the standard 4kB limit. This reduces memory consumption and increases host performance. Transparent Hugepage support uses the transparent_hugepages element.

example.title: Setting Transparent Hugepage memory management
example.screen:
PUT /restapi-definition/hosts/2ab5e1da-b726-4274-bbf7-0a42b16a0fc3 HTTP/1.1 Accept: application/xml Content-Type: application/xml
<host id="2ab5e1da-b726-4274-bbf7-0a42b16a0fc3" href="/restapi-definition/hosts/2ab5e1da-b726-4274-bbf7-0a42b16a0fc3"> <name>host1</name> <status>UP</status> ... <transparent_hugepages>true</transparent_hugepages> </host>

section.para: Availability of Transparent Hugepage support is found in the capabilities collection. See .

section.title: Network Interface Sub-Collection
section.para: The nics sub-collection represents a host's physical network interfaces. Each host_nic element in the representation acts as a network interface and contains the following properties:

note.title: Element property icons
note.para: The icons used in the properties column of this table are described in

row.entry: The name of the host network interface, e.g. eth0

footnote.para: Only required when adding bonded interfaces. Other interfaces are read-only and cannot be added.

row.entry: A reference to the network, if any, that the interface is attached to

footnote.para: Only required when adding bonded interfaces. Other interfaces are read-only and cannot be added.

row.entry: The MAC address of the interface
The IP level configuration of the interface
The protocol for IP address assignment when the host is booting. A list of enumerated values is available in capabilities. See
The network interface speed in bits per second
The link status for the network interface
The VLAN which this interface represents, if any
A list of options and slave NICs for bonded interfaces

footnote.para: Only required when adding bonded interfaces. Other interfaces are read-only and cannot be added.

row.entry: A reference to the master bonded interface, if this is a slave interface

example.title: An XML representation of a network interface on a host
example.screen: <host_nic id="e8f02fdf-3d7b-4135-86e1-1bf185570cd8" href="/restapi-definition/hosts/2ab5e1da-b726-4274-bbf7-0a42b16a0fc3/nics/ e8f02fdf-3d7b-4135-86e1-1bf185570cd8"> <name>bond0</name> <host id="2ab5e1da-b726-4274-bbf7-0a42b16a0fc3" href="/restapi-definition/hosts/2ab5e1da-b726-4274-bbf7-0a42b16a0fc3"/> <network id="e657d631-657d-42bb-a536-73501a085d85" href="/restapi-definition/networks/e657d631-657d-42bb-a536-73501a085d85"/> <mac address="D6:76:F1:3A:AF:74"/> <ip address="192.168.0.128" netmask="255.255.255.0" gateway="192.168.0.1"/> <boot_protocol>dhcp</boot_protocol> <speed>1000000000</speed> <status>UP</status> <bonding> <options> ... </options> <slaves> <host_nic id="eb14e154-5e73-4f7f-bf6b-7f52609d94ec"/> <host_nic id="6aede5ca-4c54-4b37-a81b-c0d6b53558ea"/> </slaves> </bonding> <actions> <link rel="attach" href="/restapi-definition/hosts/2ab5e1da-b726-4274-bbf7-0a42b16a0fc3/nics/ e8f02fdf-3d7b-4135-86e1-1bf185570cd8/attach"/> <link rel="detach" href="/restapi-definition/hosts/2ab5e1da-b726-4274-bbf7-0a42b16a0fc3/nics/ e8f02fdf-3d7b-4135-86e1-1bf185570cd8/detach"/> </actions> </host_nic>

section.para: An API user creates only bonded interfaces (see ). All other network interfaces contain updatable network, ip and boot_protocol properties using a PUT request.

section.title: Bonded Interfaces
section.para: A bonded interface is represented as a host_nic resource containing a bonding element, which contains the following properties:

row.entry: A list of option elements for a bonded interface. Each option contains property name and value attributes.

footnote.para: Only required when adding bonded interfaces. Other interfaces are read-only and cannot be added.

row.entry: A list of slave host_nic id= elements for a bonded interface

footnote.para: Only required when adding bonded interfaces. Other interfaces are read-only and cannot be added.

section.para: An API user creates a new bond when POSTing to a host_nic with bonding options and slave interfaces. The name, network and bonded elements are required when creating a new bonded interface. Either the id or name elements identify the network and slave host_nics.

example.title: Creating a bonded interface
example.screen:
POST /restapi-definition/hosts/2ab5e1da-b726-4274-bbf7-0a42b16a0fc3/nics HTTP/1.1 Accept: application/xml Content-Type: application/xml
<host_nic> <name>bond4</name> <network id="e657d631-657d-42bb-a536-73501a085d85"/> <bonding> <options> ... </options> <slaves> <host_nic id="eb14e154-5e73-4f7f-bf6b-7f52609d94ec"/> <host_nic id="6aede5ca-4c54-4b37-a81b-c0d6b53558ea"/> </slaves> </bonding> </host_nic>

note.para: bond0, bond1, bond2, bond3 and bond4 are the only valid names for a bonded interface.

section.para: Like other resources, a DELETE request to a bonded interface URI deletes it.

warning.para: Changes to bonded interface configuration must be explicitly committed. See .

section.title: Attach Action
section.para: A host network interface is attached to a network, indicating the given network is accessible over the interface. Either the id or name elements identify the network.

example.title: Action to attach a host network interface to a network
example.screen:
POST /restapi-definition/hosts/2ab5e1da-b726-4274-bbf7-0a42b16a0fc3/nics/e8f02fdf-3d7b-4135-86e1-1bf185570cd8/attach HTTP/1.1 Content-type: application/xml
<action> <network id="e657d631-657d-42bb-a536-73501a085d85"/> </action>

warning.para: This networking configuration change must be explicitly committed. See .

section.title: Detach Action
section.para: Detach an interface from a network. Either the id or name elements identify the network.

example.title: Action to deattach a host network interface to a network
example.screen:
POST /restapi-definition/hosts/2ab5e1da-b726-4274-bbf7-0a42b16a0fc3/nics/e8f02fdf-3d7b-4135-86e1-1bf185570cd8/detach HTTP/1.1 Content-type: application/xml
<action> <network id="e657d631-657d-42bb-a536-73501a085d85"/> </action>

warning.para: This networking configuration change must be explicitly committed. See .

section.title: Storage Sub-Collection
section.para: The storage sub-collection provides a list of the iSCSI and FCP storage representations available on the host. This storage is used to create storage domains, as described in .
Each storage representation in the sub-collection represents a SCSI LUN.

example.title: An XML representation of the storage sub-collection on a host
example.screen: <host_storage> <storage id="82fb123b-321e-40a1-9889-95dcd2654463" href="/restapi-definition/hosts/2ab5e1da-b726-4274-bbf7-0a42b16a0fc3/storage/ 82fb123b-321e-40a1-9889-95dcd2654463"> <name>LUN0</name> <type>iscsi</type> <logical_unit id="LUN0"> <address>mysan.example.com</address> <target>iqn.2009-08.com.example:mysan.foobar</target> </logical_unit> </storage> </host_storage>

section.title: Statistics Sub-Collection
section.para: Each host resource exposes a statistics sub-collection for host-specific statistics. Each statistic contains the following properties.

row.entry: The unique identifier for the statistic entry
A plain text description of the statistic
The unit or rate to measure the statistical values
The data type for the statistical values that follow
A data set that contains datum
An individual piece of data from a value
A relationship to the containing host resource

example.title: An XML representation of the host's statistics sub-collection
example.screen: <statistics> <statistic id="4ae97794-f56d-3f05-a9e7-8798887cd1ac" href="/restapi-definition/hosts/2ab5e1da-b726-4274-bbf7-0a42b16a0fc3/ statistics/4ae97794-f56d-3f05-a9e7-8798887cd1ac"> <name>memory.total</name> <description>Total memory</description> <unit>BYTES</unit> <type>GUAGE</type> <values type="INTEGER"> <value> <datum>3983540224<datum> </value> </values> <host id="2ab5e1da-b726-4274-bbf7-0a42b16a0fc3" href="/restapi-definition/hosts/2ab5e1da-b726-4274-bbf7-0a42b16a0fc3"/> </statistic> <statistic id="a98c1e11-078c-3593-a57e-4b12c1ce9815" href="/restapi-definition/hosts/2ab5e1da-b726-4274-bbf7-0a42b16a0fc3/ statistics/a98c1e11-078c-3593-a57e-4b12c1ce9815"> <name>cpu.current.system</name> <description>System CPU usage</description> <unit>PERCENT</unit> <type>GUAGE</type> <values type="DECIMAL"> <value> <datum>12<datum> </value> </values> <host id="2ab5e1da-b726-4274-bbf7-0a42b16a0fc3" href="/restapi-definition/hosts/2ab5e1da-b726-4274-bbf7-0a42b16a0fc3"/> </statistic> ... </statistics>

note.para: A host's statistics sub-collection is read-only.

section.title: Actions
section.para: The following sections describe the actions associated with host resources.
The API contains a number of possible actions for hosts: install, activate, fence, deactivate, approve, iscsilogin, iscsidiscover and commitnetconfig.

section.title: Install Action
section.para: Install VDSM and related software on the host. The host type defines additional parameters for the action.

listitem.para: Red Hat Enterprise Linux host - This host type requires an root_password element that refers to the password for the host's root user.
Red Hat Enterprise Virtualization Hypervisor host - This host type requires an image element that refers to an ISO file stored on the Red Hat Enterprise Virtualization Manager server.

example.title: Action to install VDSM to a Red Hat Enterprise Linux host
example.screen:
POST /restapi-definition/hosts/2ab5e1da-b726-4274-bbf7-0a42b16a0fc3/install HTTP/1.1 Content-type: application/xml
<action> <root_password>p@55w0Rd!</root_password> </action>

example.title: Action to install VDSM to a Red Hat Enterprise Virtualization Hypervisor host
example.screen:
POST /restapi-definition/hosts/2ab5e1da-b726-4274-bbf7-0a42b16a0fc3/install HTTP/1.1 Content-type: application/xml
<action> <image>/usr/share/rhev-hypervisor/rhev-hypervisor.iso</image> </action>

section.title: Activate Action
section.para: Activate the host for use, such as running virtual machines.

example.title: Action to activate a host
example.screen:
POST /restapi-definition/hosts/2ab5e1da-b726-4274-bbf7-0a42b16a0fc3/activate HTTP/1.1 Content-type: application/xml
<action/>

section.title: Fence Action
section.para: An API user controls a host's power management device with the fence action. See for details on configuring a fencing device for a host.
The capabilities lists available fence_type options. See for details on accessing this list.

example.title: Action to fence a host
example.screen:
POST /restapi-definition/hosts/2ab5e1da-b726-4274-bbf7-0a42b16a0fc3/fence Content-Type: application/xml
<action> <fence_type>start</fence_type> </action>

section.title: Deactivate Action
section.para: Deactivate the host to perform maintenance tasks.

example.title: Action to deactivate a host
example.screen:
POST /restapi-definition/hosts/2ab5e1da-b726-4274-bbf7-0a42b16a0fc3/deactivate HTTP/1.1 Content-type: application/xml
<action/>

section.title: Approve Action
section.para: Approve a pre-installed Red Hat Enterprise Virtualization Hypervisor host for usage in the vitualization environment. This action also accepts an optional cluster element to define the target cluster for this host.

example.title: Action to approve a host
example.screen:
POST /restapi-definition/hosts/2ab5e1da-b726-4274-bbf7-0a42b16a0fc3/approve HTTP/1.1 Content-type: application/xml
<action> <cluster id="99408929-82cf-4dc7-a532-9d998063fa95"/> <action>

section.title: iSCSI Login Action
section.para: The iscsilogin action enables a host to login to an iSCSI target. Logging into a target makes the contained LUNs available in the host_storage collection. See .

example.title: Action to enable a host to login to iSCSI target
example.screen:
POST /restapi-definition/hosts/2ab5e1da-b726-4274-bbf7-0a42b16a0fc3/iscsilogin HTTP/1.1 Content-Type: application/xml Accept: application/xml
<action> <iscsi> <address>mysan.example.com</address> <target>iqn.2009-08.com.example:mysan.foobar</target> <username>jimmy</username> <password>s3kr37</password> </iscsi> </action>

section.title: iSCSI Discover Action
section.para: The iscsidiscover action enables an iSCSI portal to be queried for its list of LUNs.

example.title: Action to query a list of LUNs for iSCSI portal
example.screen:
POST /restapi-definition/hosts/2ab5e1da-b726-4274-bbf7-0a42b16a0fc3/iscsidiscover HTTP/1.1 Content-Type: application/xml Accept: application/xml
<action> <iscsi> <address>mysan.example.com</address> </iscsi> </action>
HTTP/1.1 202 Accept Content-Type: application/xml
<action id="e9126d04-0f74-4e1a-9139-13f11fcbb4ab" href="/restapi-definition/hosts/2ab5e1da-b726-4274-bbf7-0a42b16a0fc3/iscsidiscover/ e9126d04-0f74-4e1a-9139-13f11fcbb4ab"> <iscsi_target>iqn.2009-08.com.example:mysan.foobar</iscsi_target> ... <action>

section.title: Commit Network Configuration Action
section.para: An API user commits the network configuration to persist a host network interface attachment or detachment, or persist the creation and deletion of a bonded interface.

example.title: Action to commit network configuration
example.screen:
POST /restapi-definition/hosts/2ab5e1da-b726-4274-bbf7-0a42b16a0fc3/commitnetconfig HTTP/1.1 Content-type: application/xml
<action/>

warning.para: Networking configuration is only committed after the Manager has established that host connectivity is not lost as a result of the configuration changes. If host connectivity is lost, the host requires a reboot and automatically reverts to the previous networking configuration.
